questions.question_text:
A technician receives a phone call regarding ransomware that has been detected on a PC in a remote office.
Which of the following steps should the technician take FIRST?

discussion.content:
1. Identify and research malware symptoms.
2. Quarantine the infected systems.
3. Disable System Restore (in Windows).
4. Remediate the infected systems.
5. Schedule scans and run updates.
6. Enable System Restore and create a restore point (in Windows).
7. Educate the end user.
I think the answer is B because of the wording in this question, key words are REMOTE OFFICE and FIRST. Perform a scan is what should be done first because the other answers don't make sense.

I would suggest - since tech doesn't have access to infected machine (at the time ticket is created) - to run remote scanning to reduce risks and move on to site after - to proceed with quarantine of the machine.

comments.content: It's a REMOTE OFFICE gotta read the question carefully, out of a these B is what can and should be done FIRST.

Step 1 (Identify) has already been done, obviously by the local security software scanning. Step 2 is Quarantine to prevent spread (the speed of this Step critical especially with ransomware and worms). 
Also, remote scanning doesn't nothing to reduce risks. Your suggestion will likely lead to further infections around the network and your job being on shaky ground.

discussion.content: I guess disconnecting the pc from the network is a form of Quarantine. So id agree with answer A.

choices.A: Disconnect the PC from the network

choices.C: Rerun the antivirus scan with higher sensitivity
choices.D: Rebuild the OS on the machine
choices.B: Do a System Restore to a date before the infection
choices.A: Check the contents of the hosts file

questions.question_text:
A technician performs a virus cleaning on a computer that has been redirecting all browsers to a phishing website. System Restore was turned off before the cleaning. The technician runs the machine through several scanners, and then tests for redirection. A smaller number of sites are still redirecting to the phishing website. The antivirus software correctly blocks the website.
Which of the following should the technician do NEXT?

discussion.content:
A is correct.
The hosts file is a local plain text file that maps servers or hostnames to IP addresses. This file has been in use since the time of ARPANET. It was the original method to resolve hostnames to a specific IP address. The hosts file is usually the first process in the domain name resolution procedure.

choices.E: Program file permissions have changed recently
choices.C: The OS has been updated recently
choices.D: There are disabled services on the vendor website
choices.F: There is a rogue anti-malware program

discussion.content: According to the All-in-One A+ Exam Guide by Mike Meyers "Some free anti-malware applications are actually malware- what techs call rogue anti-malware programs. You can avoid these rogue applications by sticking to the recommended lists of anti-malware software found online at reputable tech sites..."
Bad/incomplete question. Get the proxy part. Don't understand why the pop-ups are coming up at work and not when away from work. Same computer? Different computer? What exactly?

comments.content: It doesn't say the pop ups are from the vendor site. The user could have downloaded a rogue antivirus and that malware is creating pop up windows.

discussion.content: rogue anti-malware - Free applications that claim to be anti-malware, but which are actually themselves malware.
This is a really poorly worded question, like quite a few on here, and doesn't provide enough context to get a concrete answer

comments.content: You described a huge swath of of CompTIA questions, but also a majority if technician-customer interactions.
I was confused by this too, i'm assuming it's badly worded and means it was fine when he tried but failed when he tried on the user's system.

"The technician is able to log in successfully before going to the office. However, the technician is unable to log in when in the user's office" Which system has the problem, the user's or the technician's? The tech suddenly developed a system problem at the user's office?

You are conflating system notifications and pop ups but they are not the same thing. Deleting system files would not necessarily lead to notifications either, as the system will recreate missing files in some cases. Deleted system files would also not be specifically preventing the user from accessing the vendor website.

P.S. Rogue software can change the proxy settings along with lots of other settings so the two options are actually linked.
Rogue software and missing files are also linked but this pair does not fit the question.

discussion.content: The problem i have with this question is that the most common source of "pop ups" is not rogue anti-malware. Its adware. this question does not actually provide enough information for me to arrive a the conclusion that I am looking at a rogue anti- malware issue. I am more likely to believe that System files were deleted. Wouldn't that lead to system notification "pop ups"?

comments.content: I stand corrected, "rogue anti-malware" are those bogus "fake anti-virus" softwares
I believe it's referring to a false positive, as in, your anti-malware software is blocking this website despite the site being safe, hence the anti-malware software is "rogue"

Rogue anti-malware software/ programs is a type of malware that infects a computer and generated false security reports claiming that the computer is infected. in order to convince the user to pay for the removal. it's like ransom ware without the locking of files.

discussion.content: doesn't anti-malware imply it blocks malware, should it not be rogue malware ?

questions.question_text:
A user calls a technician to report issues when logging in to a vendor's website. The technician is able to log in successfully before going to the office. However, the technician is unable to log in when in the user's office. The user also informs the technician of strange pop-up notifications.
Which of the following are the MOST likely causes of these issues? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: If we were to stick with the question as worded, the correct answer here is "Device Compatibility" since there supposedly is some old hardware out there that can't use WPA. But if this question was supposed to ask why use WPA over WEP, THEN the answer given here would be correct.
Isn't WPA more secure than WEP? So why would increased security be the answer here???

comments.content:
They obviously typed in the two protocols backward in the answer. WPA is clearly more secure than WEP, so looking at the answers, we can see this is what is going on fairly readily. Or at least I could.

Maybe thats why Ive never failed a CompTIA exam yet and find them fairly simple though, so who knows

discussion.content: Reason to use WEP is Compatability and reason to use WPA is security.

You actually don't have to look deeper into it even though CompTIA makes us second guess ourselves we have trust issues with like every question. In the CompTIA 1002 Sybex study guide it says "WPA implements most—but not all—of 802.11i to communicate with older wireless cards." So it's not that the question is wrong, it's just asking you for an answer to a weird situation we'll probably never run into. WPA is not compatible with some older wireless cards hence why you sometimes should and can only use WEP
A. Device compatibility

The question is worded correctly. I have seen similar questions on measureup and totalsems and the correct answer they give is along the lines of, "when using legacy equipment where wpa is not supported."

Typically I'd go with the exam topics answer but I see 2 other exam prep sites that support "device compatibility" and 2 other sites that support "increased security". Obviously its device compatibility but we're working with CompTIA so who knows.
WPA-AES is the most secure, I've seen questions asking the same as here, It did not have AES listed in the answer....
. Device compatibility

comments.content: Exactly, it is that saying WEP over WPA!

discussion.content:
You all are missing the point. 

Clearly WPA is more secure than WEP, however the question is if you can find any reason to use WEP instead of WPA, and the answer is 'Device compatibility'. Thus 'A' is correct.
Ive seen exactly the same question on itexams.com and the answer is A) device compatibility. This would make sense if its an old device that doesnt support WPA or WPA2
I think is A. Device compatibility
The question* is WEP over WPA, it's the answer that's wrong

You've got to be kidding me....

Is the real test worded this way?
Thought that WEP was only used in the case of Legacy Equipment, but since that's not an answer would have to go with Device compatibility. Pretty sure this question is worded all wrong
its wrong wpa2 eas wep is used when the device is only compatible with wep and nothing else

comments.content: as long as we know that WPA is safer than WEP, if the wording was wrong on this exam, we'll know what to choose when we get the real one
yep mistakes are fine , but are they being corrected ? i take it 8 month later nope

discussion.content: It might have been worded wrong guys, it probably meant to say WPA over WEP. You know I think these questions are entered here manually. Humans make mistakes.
This question is wrong, it should be WPA over WEP, then the answer is Increased Security
lol answer is device compatibility
I agree with your 2nd comment. More than likely the brain dump question is incorreclty worded.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a reason to use WEP over WPA?

choices.D: Restore Windows to a previous date

discussion.content:
Even your browser and anti-malware applications can turn against you. If you type in one Web address and end up at a different site than you anticipated, a malware infection might have overwritten your hosts file.

Meyers, Mike. CompTIA A+ Certification All-in-One Exam Guide, Tenth Edition (Exams 220-1001 & 220-1002) (p. 1274). McGraw-Hill Education.
Sometimes malware is known to make changes to the host file
Process of elimination plays a huge part in a question like this, only logical answer is B

questions.question_text:
When a user browses to a favorite website on a Windows laptop, a different website opens. A technician installs an additional web browser, but it also opens to the same unfamiliar site. The technician resets the web browser settings back to default, but the issue persists.
Which of the following troubleshooting steps should the technician complete NEXT?
